subject: Re: [junit] Re:Re: Re:Re: Ask some questions about source code of JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I apologize for the confusion. It looks like TestRunListener was added as an extension point, but is not in use. I think it should be removed. It probably
messageBody:
F. Don wrote:

> Dear J. B. Rainsberger,
>
> >> Thank you, I find it.
> >> But I still don't understand how BaseTestRunner implement the interface
> >> TestRunListener.
> >> In class BaseTestRunner, there is an explanation "// TestRunListener
> >> implementation" before "public abstract void testStarted(String
> >> testName);" Then how can BaseTestRunner implement it? The
> signature of
> >> BaseTestRunner is "public abstract class BaseTestRunner implements
> >> TestListener", so it implements two interfaces, TestListener and
> >> TestRunListener?
> >
> >In Java, an abstract class can implement an interface even if all the
> >methods are abstract.
> >
> >BaseTestRunner is a base class itself. Its subclasses implement the
> >TestRunListener methods. Declaring that BaseTestRunner implements
> >TestRunListener, but declaring all the methods abstract removes
> duplication.
>
> I know it is an abstract class.
> But abstract class BaseTestRunner implements TestListener, not
> implements TestRunListener.
> please note: TestListener, not TestRunListener.
> I am fuzzed. :(

I apologize for the confusion. It looks like TestRunListener was added
as an extension point, but is not in use. I think it should be removed.
It probably never will be.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
